case_name: Union of India v. A.V. Narasimhalu

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1361 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 5, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 1287 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1361 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 5, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 1287 of 1960. Niren De, Attorney-General, V. A. Seyid Muhammad, R.N. Sachthey and S.P. Nayar, for the appellant.

facts.text: A.V. Narasimhalu, the plaintiff, imported 43 reels of newsprint of 13 1/4 inch width under a bill of Entry dated July 15, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: A.V. Narasimhalu--hereinafter called the plaintiff imported 43 reels of newsprint 131/4 width under a bill of Entry dated July 15, 1954. The width of the newsprint being less than 15 numberimport duty was payable under the Open General Licence The Assistant Collector of Customs held that the companymodity imported fell within item 44 of the Customs Tariff and levied a duty of 33 3/8 ad valorem.

facts.text: The width of the newsprint imported by the plaintiff was less than 15 inches and no import duty was payable under the Open General Licence.

anchor.surface_text: The width of the newsprint being less than 15 numberimport duty was payable under the Open General Licence The Assistant Collector of Customs held that the companymodity imported fell within item 44 of the Customs Tariff and levied a duty of 33 3/8 ad valorem. The plaintiff paid the duty under protest, and applied for refund of the duty relying upon a decision of the High Court o.f Madras in writ petition No. 402 of 1954 in which it was decided that newsprint of width less than 15 was exempt from duty.

facts.text: The Assistant Collector of Customs held that the imported newsprint fell within item 44 of the Customs Tariff and levied a duty of 33 3/8% ad valorem.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector of Customs held that the companymodity imported fell within item 44 of the Customs Tariff and levied a duty of 33 3/8 ad valorem. The plaintiff paid the duty under protest, and applied for refund of the duty relying upon a decision of the High Court o.f Madras in writ petition No. 402 of 1954 in which it was decided that newsprint of width less than 15 was exempt from duty. This application was rejected.

facts.text: The plaintiff paid the customs duty under protest.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff paid the duty under protest, and applied for refund of the duty relying upon a decision of the High Court o.f Madras in writ petition No. 402 of 1954 in which it was decided that newsprint of width less than 15 was exempt from duty. This application was rejected. An appeal to the Collector of Customs and a revision application to the Central Board of Revenue were unsuccessful.

facts.text: The plaintiff applied for refund of the duty relying on Madras High Court decision in writ petition No. 402 of 1954 that newsprint of width less than 15 was exempt from duty.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff paid the duty under protest, and applied for refund of the duty relying upon a decision of the High Court o.f Madras in writ petition No. 402 of 1954 in which it was decided that newsprint of width less than 15 was exempt from duty. facts.text: The plaintiff's appeal to the Collector of Customs was unsuccessful.

facts.text: In Secretary of State for India v. Mask & Co., importers of betelnuts had them assessed as boiled by Assistant Collector, appeal to Collector dismissed, revision to Government of India affirmed.

anchor.surface_text: In Mask Companys case 1  a firm of merchants imported a quantity of betelnuts into. British India. The Assistant Collector of Customs assessed them for the purposes of duty on a tariff as boiled, rejecting the companytention of the importers, that they Were raw sliced betel-nuts subject to duty ad valorem. The importers, appealed from the decision of the Assistant Collector to the Collector of Customs. The appeal was dismissed, and in revision to the Government of India the Collectors decision was affirmed.

facts.text: The Attorney-General stated that the Union of India will refund the amount of tax unauthorisedly recovered by the Assistant Collector of Customs regardless of the decision in the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We are glad to record the assurance given by the Attorney General that whatever may be the decision in the appeal, the Union of India will refund the amount of tax unauthorised recovered by the Assistant Collector of Customs. This was essentially a case in which when numberice was served the Central Government should instead of relying upon technicalities have refunded the amount companylected.

Section 188 of the Sea Customs Act, 1878, insofar as it is relevant, provides Any person deeming himself aggrieved by any decision or order passed b.y an officer of Customs under L.R. 67 I.A. 222. this Act may, within three months from the date of such decision or order, appeal therefrom to the Chief Customs Authority, or in such cases as the Central Government directs, to any officer of Customs number inferior in rank to a Customs Collector and empowered in that behalf by name or in virtue of his office by the Central Government. Section 188 of the Sea Customs Act, 1878, insofar as it is relevant, provides Any person deeming himself aggrieved by any decision or order passed b.y an officer of Customs under L.R. 67 I.A. 222. this Act may, within three months from the date of such decision or order, appeal therefrom to the Chief Customs Authority,

issues.text: Whether by refusing to appeal under s. 188 or claim relief under s. 191 a party may invest the Civil Court with jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Section 191 provides The Central Government may, on the application of any person aggrieved by any decision or order passed under this Act by any officer of Customs or Chief Customs Authority, and from which numberappeal lies, reverse or modify such decision or order. The Act is a companyplete companye dealing with liability to pay customs duty and for obtaining relief against excessive or erroneous levy and other related matters. The jurisdiction of the Civil Court to entertain a suit on the ground that the duty was improperly or illegally levied is excluded.

issues.text: Whether the Sea Customs Act constitutes a complete code excluding Civil Court jurisdiction where duty is improperly or illegally levied

anchor.surface_text: The Act is a companyplete companye dealing with liability to pay customs duty and for obtaining relief against excessive or erroneous levy and other related matters. The jurisdiction of the Civil Court to entertain a suit on the ground that the duty was improperly or illegally levied is excluded. It is true that the decision or order passed under s. 188 of the Sea Customs Act in appeal to the appellate authority is expressly declared final.

issues.text: Whether the question is whether the Collector could be said to be acting within his jurisdiction if he levied duty on goods not liable to duty in disregard of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in the judgment under appeal observed the question in these. appeals is different, namely, whether the Collector companyld be said to be acting within his jurisdiction, if he, in direct disregard of the provisions of the Act and the Rules made thereunder, levied a duty upon the goods which were number liable to duty and companypelled by duress as it were the importer to pay the same before taking delivery of the goods.

issues.text: Whether the Customs Authority violated fundamental principles of judicial procedure, acted ultra vires, without competence, or mala fide

anchor.surface_text: It may be observed that it was number the case that the Assistant Collector of Customs had number acted in companyformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure, number was it the case that the provisions of the Act were ultra vires or unconstitutional.... We, however, deem it necessary to observe that the civil companyrts have jurisdiction to examine cases in which the Customs Authority has number companyplied with the provisions of the statute or the officer of customs has number acted in companyformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure or the Authority has acted in violation of the fundamental principles of judicial procedure or he has made an order which is number within his companypetence or the statute which imposes liability is unconstitutional, or where the order is alleged to be mala fide.

issues.text: Whether the principles in Dhulabhai relating to exclusion of Civil Court jurisdiction apply

anchor.surface_text: In a recent judgment of this Court Dhulabhai etc. v. State Madhya Pradesh and Anr. 1 this Court set out certain principles relating to the exclusion of the jurisdiction of the Civil Court. The propositions 1 , 2 , 5 , 6 7 are relevant.

arguments.claim: Section 188 Sea Customs Act provides appeal to Chief Customs Authority, order final subject to s.191 revision

anchor.surface_text: Section 188 of the Sea Customs Act, 1878, insofar as it is relevant, provides Any person deeming himself aggrieved by any decision or order passed b.y an officer of Customs under L.R. 67 I.A. 222. this Act may, within three months from the date of such decision or order, appeal therefrom to the Chief Customs Authority, or in such cases as the Central Government directs, to any officer of Customs number inferior in rank to a Customs Collector and empowered in that behalf by name or in virtue of his office by the Central Government.

arguments.claim: Section 191 provides revision by Central Government

anchor.surface_text: Section 191 provides The Central Government may, on the application of any person aggrieved by any decision or order passed under this Act by any officer of Customs or Chief Customs Authority, and from which numberappeal lies, reverse or modify such decision or order.

arguments.claim: Sea Customs Act is complete code excluding civil court jurisdiction for improper or illegal levy of duty

anchor.surface_text: The Act is a companyplete companye dealing with liability to pay customs duty and for obtaining relief against excessive or erroneous levy and other related matters. The jurisdiction of the Civil Court to entertain a suit on the ground that the duty was improperly or illegally levied is excluded.

arguments.claim: Refusing to appeal under s.188 or seek s.191 relief does not invest civil court with jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the decision or order passed under s. 188 of the Sea Customs Act in appeal to the appellate authority is expressly declared final. But on that account it cannot be held that by refusing to appeal against the decision or by refusing to claim relief in the manner provided by s. 188 and s. 191 of the Sea Customs Act, a party aggrieved by the order of a Customs Officer may invest the Civil Court with jurisdiction to entertain a suit.

arguments.claim: Mask & Co. holds that customs decisions under s.188 final, exclude civil jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: In Mask Companys case 1  a firm of merchants imported a quantity of betelnuts into. British India. The Assistant Collector of Customs assessed them for the purposes of duty on a tariff as boiled, rejecting the companytention of the importers, that they Were raw sliced betel-nuts subject to duty ad valorem. The importers, appealed from the decision of the Assistant Collector to the Collector of Customs.

arguments.claim: Dhulabhai principles (propositions 1,2,5,6,7) on exclusion of civil jurisdiction apply

anchor.surface_text: In a recent judgment of this Court Dhulabhai etc. v. State Madhya Pradesh and Anr.  1  this Court set out certain principles relating to the exclusion of the jurisdiction of the Civil Court. The propositions  1 ,  2 ,  5 ,  6   7  are relevant.

arguments.claim: No violation of fundamental principles of judicial procedure, no ultra vires, no lack of competence, no mala fides

anchor.surface_text: It may be observed that it was number the case that the Assistant Collector of Customs had number acted in companyformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure, number was it the case that the provisions of the Act were ultra vires or unconstitutional.

arguments.claim: Erroneous customs decision not beyond jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: But an erroneous decision of the Customs Authority cannot be said to be reached without jurisdiction merely because it may be shown in some companylateral proceeding to be wrong.

arguments.claim: Customs duty liability created by statute with complete machinery, excludes civil court

anchor.surface_text: Normally an action of an administrative authority interfering with the right to property may be challanged by resort to a civil companyrt, Yet in the case of a right which depends upon a statute, the jurisdiction of the civil companyrt to grant relief may by express provision or by clear implication of the statute be excluded.

arguments.claim: Civil courts retain jurisdiction only for non-compliance with statute, natural justice violation, ultra vires, incompetence, unconstitutionality, mala fides

anchor.surface_text: We, however, deem it necessary to observe that the civil companyrts have jurisdiction to examine cases in which the Customs Authority has number companyplied with the provisions of the statute or the officer of customs has number acted in companyformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure or the Authority has acted in violation of the fundamental principles of judicial procedure or he has made an order which is number within his companypetence or the statute which imposes liability is unconstitutional, or where the order is alleged to be mala fide.

arguments.claim: Union of India will refund the tax unauthorisedly recovered regardless of appeal decision

anchor.surface_text: We are glad to record the assurance given by the Attorney General that whatever may be the decision in the appeal, the Union of India will refund the amount of tax unauthorised recovered by the Assistant Collector of Customs.

holdings.text: the Civil Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the suit

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to consider whether the claim is barred under s. 40 of the Sea Customs Act, for, in our judgment, the Civil Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sea Customs Act provides complete machinery via s.188 appeal and s.191 revision, excluding civil jurisdiction; follows Mask & Co. and Dhulabhai principles

holdings.text: The Act is a complete code dealing with liability to pay customs duty and for obtaining relief against excessive or erroneous levy and other related matters. The jurisdiction of the Civil Court to entertain a suit on the ground that the duty was improperly or illegally levied is excluded.

anchor.surface_text: The Act is a complete code dealing with liability to pay customs duty and for obtaining relief against excessive or erroneous levy and other related matters. The jurisdiction of the Civil Court to entertain a suit on the ground that the duty was improperly or illegally levied is excluded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute creates liability and provides hierarchy of tribunals (s.188, s.191); clear implication excludes civil courts where complete redress machinery exists

holdings.text: by refusing to appeal against the decision or by refusing to claim relief in the manner provided by s. 188 and s. 191 of the Sea Customs Act, a party aggrieved by the order of a Customs Officer may [not] invest the Civil Court with jurisdiction to entertain a suit

anchor.surface_text: But on that account it cannot be held that by refusing to appeal against the decision or by refusing to claim relief in the manner provided by s. 188 and s. 191 of the Sea Customs Act, a party aggrieved by the order of a Customs Officer may invest the Civil Court with jurisdiction to entertain a suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Finality under s.188 does not permit bypassing statutory remedies to invoke civil court; party cannot opt out to create jurisdiction

holdings.text: the decision of the Collector under s. 188 was final and excluded the jurisdiction of the Civil Court

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee observed that adjudication as to confiscations, increased rates of duty or penalties made under the power conferred by s. 182 were decisions or orders within the meaning of s. 188, and that the decision of the Collector under s. 188 was final and excluded the jurisdiction of the Civil Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies precedent from Mask & Co. directly to facts involving customs duty assessment

holdings.text: certain principles relating to the exclusion of the jurisdiction of the Civil Court [from Dhulabhai]... The propositions 1, 2, 5, 6, 7 are relevant

anchor.surface_text: In a recent judgment of this Court Dhulabhai etc. v. State of Madhya Pradesh and Anr. this Court set out certain principles relating to the exclusion of the jurisdiction of the Civil Court. The propositions 1, 2, 5, 6 7 are relevant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dhulabhai propositions on ouster of civil jurisdiction by special statutes apply to Sea Customs Act

holdings.text: it was not the case that the Assistant Collector of Customs had not acted in conformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure, nor was it the case that the provisions of the Act were ultra vires or unconstitutional

anchor.surface_text: It may be observed that it was not the case that the Assistant Collector of Customs had not acted in conformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure, nor was it the case that the provisions of the Act were ultra vires or unconstitutional.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of natural justice violation, ultra vires, incompetence, or mala fides; mere error not jurisdictional

holdings.text: the civil courts have jurisdiction to examine cases in which the Customs Authority has not complied with the provisions of the statute or the officer of customs has not acted in conformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure or the Authority has acted in violation of the fundamental principles of judicial procedure or he has made an order which is not within his competence or the statute which imposes liability is unconstitutional, or where the order is alleged to be mala fide

anchor.surface_text: We, however, deem it necessary to observe that the civil courts have jurisdiction to examine cases in which the Customs Authority has not complied with the provisions of the statute or the officer of customs has not acted in conformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure or the Authority has acted in violation of the fundamental principles of judicial procedure or he has made an order which is not within his competence or the statute which imposes liability is unconstitutional, or where the order is alleged to be mala fide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary observation clarifying exceptions to exclusion despite no application here; draws from Dhulabhai

holdings.text: the exclusion of the jurisdiction of the civil court to entertain a suit does not exclude the jurisdiction of the High Court to issue high prerogative writs against illegal exercise of authority by administrative or quasi-judicial tribunals
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory finality does not oust constitutional writ jurisdiction under Art.226

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed. The suit is ordered to be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed. The suit is ordered to be dismissed. The order of costs passed by the High Court is however maintained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on lack of civil jurisdiction

holdings.text: The order of costs passed by the High Court is however maintained
holdings.reasoning_summary: Equity in light of assurance to refund and avoid technicalities

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to consider whether the claim is barred under s. 40 of the Sea Customs Act, for, in our judgment, the Civil Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the suit.
The appeal is allowed. The suit is ordered to be dismissed. The order of companyts passed by the High Court is however maintained.

anchor.surface_text: assed b.y an officer of Customs under L.R. 67 I.A. 222. this Act may, within three months from the date of such decision or order, appeal therefrom to

edges.explanation: Holding that the Act is a complete code excluding jurisdiction directly addresses the issue of whether the Sea Customs Act constitutes a complete code excluding Civil Court jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Act is a complete code dealing with liability to pay customs duty and for obtaining relief against excessive or erroneous levy and other related matters. The jurisdiction of the Civil Court to entertain a suit on the ground that the duty was improperly or illegally levied is excluded.
The appeal is allowed. The suit is ordered to be dismissed. The order of companyts passed by the High Court is however maintained.

But on that account it cannot be held that by refusing to appeal against the decision or by refusing to claim relief in the manner provided by s. 188 and s. 191 of the Sea Customs Act, a party aggrieved by the order of a Customs Officer may invest the Civil Court with jurisdiction to entertain a suit.
The appeal is allowed. The suit is ordered to be dismissed. The order of companyts passed by the High Court is however maintained.
